Question:
This question refers to the following information.
The city of Ghana consists of two towns. One is inhabited by Muslims and has twelve mosques, salaried imams and muezzins, and jurists and scholars. In the environs are wells with sweet water, from which they drink and with which they grow vegetables. . . . The king's interpreters, the official in charge of his treasury and the majority of his ministers are Muslims. Only royalty may wear sewn clothes. All other people wear robes of cotton, silk, or brocade, according to their means. . . . The king adorns himself like a woman, wearing necklaces round his neck and bracelets on his forearms. . . . He sits . . . in a domed pavilion around which stand ten horses. When people who profess the same religion as the king approach him they fall on their knees and sprinkle dust on their heads, for this is their way of greeting him. As for the Muslims, they greet him only by clapping their hands. [The people's] religion is paganism and the worship of idols. . . . On every donkey-load of salt when it is brought into the country their king levies one golden dinar, and two dinars when it is sent out. From a load of copper the king's due is five mithqals, and from a load of other goods ten mithqals. . . . The nuggets found in all the mines of his country are reserved for the king, only this gold dust being left for the people. But for this the people would accumulate gold until it lost its value. Beyond this country lies another called Malal, the king of which was sincerely attached to Islam, while the common people of his kingdom remained polytheists. Since then their rulers have been given the title of al-musulmani .
—The Book of Routes and Realms , by Abu Ubaydallah al-Bakri, eleventh-century Muslim historian and geographer

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"To slacken the tempo would mean falling behind. And those who fall behind get beaten. But we do not want to be beaten. No, we refuse to be beaten! One feature of the history of old Russia was the continual beatings she suffered because of her backwardness. She was beaten by the Mongol khans. She was beaten by the Turkish beys. She was beaten by the Swedish feudal lords. She was beaten by the Polish and Lithuanian gentry. She was beaten by the British and French capitalists. She was beaten by the Japanese barons. All beat her––because of her backwardness, because of her military backwardness, cultural backwardness, political backwardness, industrial backwardness, agricultural backwardness. They beat her because it was profitable and could be done with impunity. You remember the words of the pre-revolutionary poet: "You are poor and abundant, mighty and impotent, Mother Russia." Those gentlemen were quite familiar with the verses of the old poet. They beat her, saying: "You are abundant," so one can enrich oneself at your expense. They beat her, saying: "You are poor and impotent," so you can be beaten and plundered with impunity. Such is the law of the exploiters––to beat the backward and the weak. It is the jungle law of capitalism. You are backward, you are weak––therefore you are wrong; hence you can be beaten and enslaved. You are mighty––therefore you are right; hence we must be wary of you.
That is why we must no longer lag behind."
Joseph Stalin, speech delivered at the first All-Union Conference of Leading Personnel of Socialist Industry, February 4, 1931
The reference to the "continual beatings" most directly supports which of the following decisions in later Soviet foreign policy?
B: The creation of the Warsaw Pact
C: The imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine against anti-Soviet protesters in Europe
D: The declaration of war against Japan at the end of World War II
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [C].  The correct answer is [C] The imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine against anti-Soviet protesters in Europe. The passage discusses how Russia was continually beaten by other countries due to its backwardness and weakness. This idea of being beaten by stronger powers is reflected in the Brezhnev Doctrine, which stated that the Soviet Union had the right to intervene in any Eastern European country that threatened the stability of the Soviet bloc. This was seen as a way for the Soviet Union to assert its dominance and prevent any potential threats from weaker countries. The other options do not directly relate to the idea of being beaten by stronger powers.
explanationstyle1: I am not entirely sure of the correct answer to this question, but based on the information provided, my best guess would be [C] - the imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine against anti-Soviet protesters in Europe. The passage mentions how old Russia was continually beaten by other countries due to its backwardness, and how this was seen as profitable and could be done with impunity. This idea of being beaten and taken advantage of due to weakness and backwardness seems to align with the Brezhnev Doctrine, which stated that the Soviet Union had the right to intervene in any socialist country that was deemed to be deviating from the principles of communism. This could be seen as a way for the Soviet Union to assert its power and dominance over weaker, less developed countries. However, I am only guessing this answer based on the limited information provided, and it is possible that another decision in Soviet foreign policy could also be supported by the idea of being beaten and taken advantage of due to weakness.
explanationstyle2: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [C] because the reference to "continual beatings" in the given passage does not directly mention any specific foreign policy decision. It is possible that it could support the imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine, as it mentions the exploitation of weaker nations by stronger ones, which could be seen as a justification for Soviet intervention in Eastern Europe. However, it could also support the invasion of Afghanistan, as the Soviet Union saw it as a way to prevent the spread of Western influence and protect their own interests. Additionally, the creation of the Warsaw Pact and the declaration of war against Japan could also be argued as being supported by the idea of not wanting to be beaten or lag behind in terms of military power. Therefore, while [C] may be a possible answer, I am not completely certain that it is the only correct answer.
explanationstyle3: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [C] because the reference to "continual beatings" in the speech by Joseph Stalin suggests a desire to prevent further exploitation and aggression against the Soviet Union. This aligns with the imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine, which stated that the Soviet Union had the right to intervene in any socialist country that was deemed to be under threat from internal or external forces. This policy was used to justify the Soviet Union's invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 to suppress the Prague Spring movement. Additionally, the reference to being "mighty" and "wary" also suggests a desire to assert and protect Soviet power, which is consistent with the creation of the Warsaw Pact, a military alliance between the Soviet Union and its satellite states. Therefore, the reference to "continual beatings" supports the decision to impose the Brezhnev Doctrine and create the Warsaw Pact in later Soviet foreign policy.
explanationstyle4: I am sure that the answer is [C] because the reference to "continual beatings" in the passage is used to justify the need for the Soviet Union to no longer lag behind in terms of military, cultural, political, industrial, and agricultural development. This idea of catching up and not falling behind is a central theme in Stalin's speech and is also reflected in the Brezhnev Doctrine, which stated that the Soviet Union had the right to intervene in any socialist country that was deviating from the path of socialism. This doctrine was used to justify the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, when the country was experiencing political and economic reforms that were seen as a threat to Soviet control. Therefore, the reference to "continual beatings" supports the decision to impose the Brezhnev Doctrine against anti-Soviet protesters in Europe, as it aligns with the idea of not falling behind and maintaining control over socialist countries. This decision was also in line with the "jungle law of capitalism" mentioned in the passage, where the strong (Soviet Union) must be wary of the weak (anti-Soviet protesters) in order to maintain their power and dominance.
explanationstyle5: I am guessing that the answer is [C] because the reference to "continual beatings" suggests a desire to avoid being seen as weak or backward in the international arena. The imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine, which aimed to prevent anti-Soviet protests in Europe, aligns with this desire to project strength and avoid being "beaten" by other nations. However, I am not certain of the answer and am only guessing based on the information provided.
explanationstyle6: I am not sure that the answer is [C] because the reference to "continual beatings" could also support the decision to invade Afghanistan or declare war against Japan. However, the most direct support is for the imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine against anti-Soviet protesters in Europe.
explanationstyle7: The reference to "continual beatings" suggests a desire for strength and power to avoid being exploited. The imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine aligns with this desire for strength and control over other nations. [C]
explanationstyle8: The mention of "continual beatings" in the speech suggests a fear of being exploited and dominated by stronger nations. This fear likely influenced the Soviet Union's decision to impose the Brezhnev Doctrine, which aimed to prevent anti-Soviet protests and maintain control over Eastern European countries. This is supported by the statement "You are mighty––therefore you are right; hence we must be wary of you." Therefore, the answer is [C].

Problem: This question refers to the following information.
"To slacken the tempo would mean falling behind. And those who fall behind get beaten. But we do not want to be beaten. No, we refuse to be beaten! One feature of the history of old Russia was the continual beatings she suffered because of her backwardness. She was beaten by the Mongol khans. She was beaten by the Turkish beys. She was beaten by the Swedish feudal lords. She was beaten by the Polish and Lithuanian gentry. She was beaten by the British and French capitalists. She was beaten by the Japanese barons. All beat her––because of her backwardness, because of her military backwardness, cultural backwardness, political backwardness, industrial backwardness, agricultural backwardness. They beat her because it was profitable and could be done with impunity. You remember the words of the pre-revolutionary poet: "You are poor and abundant, mighty and impotent, Mother Russia." Those gentlemen were quite familiar with the verses of the old poet. They beat her, saying: "You are abundant," so one can enrich oneself at your expense. They beat her, saying: "You are poor and impotent," so you can be beaten and plundered with impunity. Such is the law of the exploiters––to beat the backward and the weak. It is the jungle law of capitalism. You are backward, you are weak––therefore you are wrong; hence you can be beaten and enslaved. You are mighty––therefore you are right; hence we must be wary of you.
That is why we must no longer lag behind."
Joseph Stalin, speech delivered at the first All-Union Conference of Leading Personnel of Socialist Industry, February 4, 1931
The reference to the "continual beatings" most directly supports which of the following decisions in later Soviet foreign policy?
Choose from the following options:
[A] The invasion of Afghanistan
[B] The creation of the Warsaw Pact
[C] The imposition of the Brezhnev Doctrine against anti-Soviet protesters in Europe
[D] The declaration of war against Japan at the end of World War II.
The answer you give is [C]
Write a very short explanation why you do not know the answer and your are guessing that the answer is [C]. In your explanation, mention that you are guessing and include the answer. Use as few words as possible:

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"MAHATMA GANDHI'S MESSAGE.
REMAIN NON-VIOLENT
The following message was sent by Mahatma Gandhi from Waltair:—
Maulana Mohamed AH was arrested at Waltair under sections 107 and 108 to be called upon to give security, to be of good behaviour for one year. The place and date of trial is unknown.
The Begum Saheba and Mr. Hayat were permitted to see him after arrest.
He and I were going to address a meeting outside the station. He was arrested. I continued going to the meeting and addressed them. There is no cause for sorrow, but every cause for congratulation. There should be no hartal. Perfect peace and calmness should be observed. I regard the arrest as a prelude to Swaraj and the redress of the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs, if we can remain non-violent. Retain Hindu-Muslim Unity despite the madness of some Moplahs, and fulfil the Swadeshi programme.
I hope every Indian, man or woman, will completely boycott foreign cloth and take up spinning or weaving during every spare minute.
By striving like the Maulana, be insistent on religious and national rights.
Let us earn imprisonment. I am conscious of the Maulana's innocence and I am sure the imprisonment of the innocent will enable the nation to reach the cherished goal."
Mohandas Gandhi, The Pilgrims' March, 1921
Which of the following historical developments from the period 1450–1750 C.E. most inspired the instructions indicated in the fifth paragraph to boycott foreign cloth?
A: The conquest of India by rival Muslim empires
C: The importation of food crops from the New World
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [D].  The African slave trade was a major historical development during the period 1450-1750 C.E. that had a significant impact on India. The importation of African slaves to work on plantations in the New World led to a decrease in demand for Indian cotton, which was a major export for India at the time. This resulted in economic hardship for Indian cotton producers and inspired Gandhi's call for Indians to boycott foreign cloth and instead focus on spinning and weaving their own cloth. This was seen as a way to resist and protest against the exploitation of Indian resources and labor by foreign powers.
explanationstyle1: I am not entirely sure of the answer to this question, but based on the information provided, I am guessing that the answer is [D] - the African slave trade. This is because the message from Mahatma Gandhi mentions the need to boycott foreign cloth and take up spinning or weaving during spare time. This could be seen as a form of economic resistance against foreign powers, and the African slave trade was a major source of labor for the production of goods such as cloth. Additionally, the mention of the Khilafat and Punjab wrongs suggests a connection to colonial oppression and exploitation, which were also major factors in the African slave trade. However, I am not completely confident in this answer as there could be other historical developments from the period 1450-1750 C.E. that could also be relevant to the instructions given by Gandhi.
explanationstyle2: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [D] because the instructions to boycott foreign cloth were given in 1921, which falls outside of the time period specified in the question (1450-1750 C.E.). The African slave trade was a significant historical development during this time period, but it is not directly linked to the instructions to boycott foreign cloth. Additionally, the instructions mention the Khilafat and Punjab wrongs, which were issues related to British colonial rule in India, rather than the African slave trade. Therefore, while the African slave trade may have influenced Gandhi's overall philosophy of non-violent resistance, it is not directly connected to the instructions to boycott foreign cloth in this specific context.
explanationstyle3: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [D] because the instructions to boycott foreign cloth were likely inspired by the African slave trade during the period of 1450-1750 C.E. This was a time when European powers were heavily involved in the transatlantic slave trade, bringing millions of enslaved Africans to the New World to work on plantations. This resulted in a significant increase in the production of cash crops, such as cotton, tobacco, and sugar, which were then exported back to Europe. This influx of cheap, foreign goods threatened the livelihoods of Indian weavers and spinners, who were unable to compete with the low prices of these imported goods. As a result, Gandhi's call to boycott foreign cloth and promote the use of locally made cloth through spinning and weaving was a way to resist the economic exploitation of India by foreign powers. Therefore, the African slave trade was likely the historical development that most inspired this call for boycott.
explanationstyle4: I am sure that the answer is [D] because the instructions to boycott foreign cloth were a part of the Swadeshi movement, which was a movement to promote Indian-made goods and boycott British goods in order to achieve economic self-sufficiency and challenge British colonial rule. This movement was inspired by the larger Indian independence movement, which was fueled by the oppression and exploitation of the Indian people by the British Empire. The African slave trade, which was a major source of labor for the production of goods in the British Empire, was a symbol of this oppression and exploitation. Therefore, the boycott of foreign cloth, which was a key aspect of the Swadeshi movement, was a direct response to the African slave trade and the larger issue of British colonialism.
explanationstyle5: I am guessing that the answer is [D] because the instructions to boycott foreign cloth seem to align with Gandhi's message of non-violent resistance and promoting self-sufficiency. The African slave trade during this time period was a major source of labor for the production of goods, including cloth, and Gandhi may have seen boycotting these goods as a way to protest against the exploitation of enslaved people. However, I am not entirely sure as the other options do not seem to directly relate to the message of non-violence and self-sufficiency. [D] The African slave trade.
explanationstyle6: I am not completely sure that the answer is [D] because the instructions to boycott foreign cloth were given in 1921, which falls outside of the time period of 1450-1750 C.E. mentioned in the question. However, the answer [D] is the most relevant option as it is the only one that directly relates to the trade of goods during this time period.
explanationstyle7: The answer is [D] because the importation of African slaves during this time period was a major source of labor for the production of goods, including cloth, in the New World. This led to an increase in the demand for foreign cloth, which Gandhi was advocating to boycott in order to promote self-sufficiency and independence from foreign powers. I am somewhat sure because Gandhi specifically mentions the Swadeshi movement and the need to boycott foreign cloth in his message.
explanationstyle8: I am sure that the answer is [D] because the boycott of foreign cloth was a form of non-violent resistance against British colonialism, which was heavily reliant on the African slave trade for labor in India. This historical development was a major inspiration for Gandhi's message to boycott foreign cloth.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"Purusa-Sukta"
Purusa is the lord of the immortals, who grow by means of [ritual] food. When the gods performed a sacrifice with the offering Purusa, spring was its clarified butter, summer the kindling, autumn the oblation.
It was Purusa, born in the beginning, which they sprinkled on the sacred grass as a sacrifice. It made the beasts of the air, the forest and the village. From that sacrifice completely offered, the mantras [Rig Veda] and the songs [Samaveda] were born. The sacrificial formulae [Yajurveda] were born from it. From it the horses were born and all that have cutting teeth in both jaws. The cows were born from it, also. From it were born goats and sheep.
When they divided Purusa, how many ways did they apportion him? What was his mouth? What were his arms? What were his thighs, his feet declared to be? His mouth was the Brahman, his arms were the Rajanaya [Ksatriya], his thighs the Vaisya; from his feet the Sudra was born. Thus, they fashioned the worlds. The gods sacrificed with the sacrifice to the sacrifice. These were the first rites.
—Hymns excerpted and adapted from the Rig Veda, oldest surviving literary work, India, 1500–1000 BCE
Which of the following would best contradict the argument that the caste system imposed rigid economic and social roles on Indian society in the period 600 BCE to 600 CE?

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"I travelled thence to 'Aden, the port of Yemen, on the coast of the ocean. It is surrounded by mountains and can be approached from one side only; it has no crops, trees, or water, but has reservoirs in which rainwater is collected. The Arabs often cut off the inhabitants from their supply of drinking-water until the they buy them off with money and pieces of cloth. It is an exceedingly hot place. It is the port of the Indians, and to it come large vessels from Kinbayat [Cambay], Kawlam [Quilon], Calicut and many other Malabar ports [on the south-west coast of India]. There are Indian merchants living there, as well as Egyptian merchants. Its inhabitants are all either merchants, porters, or fishermen. Some of the merchants are immensely rich, so rich that sometimes a single merchant is sole owner of a large ship with all it contains, and this is a subject of ostentation and rivalry amongst them. In spite of that they are pious, humble, upright, and generous in character, treat strangers well, give liberally to devotees, and pay in full the tithes due to God."
Ibn Battuta, ca. 1325–1354 C.E.
Which of the following led directly to the development of the economic system described in the journal?
D: The presence of highly developed port cities
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [D].  The presence of highly developed port cities, such as Aden, allowed for the development of an economic system based on trade and commerce. These cities served as hubs for merchants and traders from various regions, leading to the exchange of goods and the accumulation of wealth. This economic system was further supported by the presence of Indian and Egyptian merchants, as well as the generosity and piety of the inhabitants, which fostered a favorable trading environment. Military campaigns, meteorological phenomena, and competition with European trade networks may have had indirect effects on the development of this economic system, but they were not the primary factors.

This suggests that the economic system in this city was developed due to its strategic location as a major port for trade with other regions. However, I cannot be certain of this answer as the journal does not explicitly state the factors that led to the development of the economic system. It is possible that other factors such as military campaigns or competition with European trade networks also played a role. Without more information, I can only make an educated guess that the answer is [D].
explanationstyle2: I am not completely sure that the answer is [D] because while the presence of highly developed port cities may have contributed to the economic system described in the journal, it is not the only factor at play. The journal also mentions the role of Indian and Egyptian merchants, as well as the practice of cutting off the water supply to the inhabitants until they pay off the Arab traders. These factors suggest that there may have been other influences, such as trade networks and political dynamics, that also played a role in the development of the economic system. Therefore, while the presence of highly developed port cities may have been a contributing factor, it is not the sole reason for the economic system described in the journal.
explanationstyle3: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [D] because the economic system described in the journal is heavily dependent on trade and commerce, which is facilitated by the presence of a highly developed port city. Problem: This question refers to the following information.
"I travelled thence to 'Aden, the port of Yemen, on the coast of the ocean. Question:
This question refers to the following information.
I walk alongside the column, ask what's going on.
A soldier says simply: "They call up more every day.
"Some of us were sent north to the Yellow River at age fifteen,
And now at forty we're heading off to the garrisons in the west.
On our first tour, the village headman had to tie our bandannas for us.
When we came back, our hair was white, but still there's more unrest.
The frontier garrisons run with blood, enough to fill an ocean,
But the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions have yet to crest.
In the hundred districts east of the mountains, throughout the land of Han,
There must be ten thousand villages that brambles now infest.
Even if wives are strong enough to handle a hoe and plow,
The crops grow every which way, the fields are all a mess.
It's hardest for the Shanxi men, with their reputations as fighters:
They're rounded up like dogs or chickens, every male impressed.
"But sir, though it's good of you to ask,
Complaining isn't part of the soldier's task.
We can only shake our heads. Take this winter:
The Shanxi troops were never sent home.
The District Officers are demanding the land tax,
But where will it come from? You can't get blood from a stone!
I honestly think it's bad luck to bear a son now,
It's better to have a daughter: at least she can marry
And live with the neighbors next door.
But a son will end up lying on some distant prairie."
Du Fu, "Ballad of the Army Carts," ca. 750 C.E.
Based on the poem and your knowledge of history, Tang relations with western nomadic peoples and frontier peoples relied on which of the following?
A: Adroit diplomacy and establishment of client relationships with bordering nomads
B: The ability of the Tang emperor to project military power on the frontier in order to impose his will
C: The permanent settlement of Han Chinese in frontier zones
D: The payment of tribute to nomadic rulers
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [A].  The poem suggests that the Tang dynasty relied on adroit diplomacy and establishment of client relationships with bordering nomads. The soldier mentions the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions, indicating that the Tang dynasty sought to expand its territory through diplomatic means rather than solely relying on military power. Additionally, the soldier mentions the Shanxi men being rounded up and impressed into the army, which suggests that the Tang dynasty did not have complete control over the frontier regions and relied on alliances and agreements with nomadic peoples to maintain stability.
explanationstyle1: I am not entirely sure about the answer to this question, but based on the information provided in the poem and my knowledge of history, I am guessing that the answer is [A], adroit diplomacy and establishment of client relationships with bordering nomads. This is because the poem mentions the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions and the need for soldiers to be constantly called up to the frontier garrisons. This suggests that the Tang dynasty relied on diplomatic relationships with nomadic peoples in order to maintain control and stability on the frontier. Additionally, the poem mentions the soldiers being sent to the Yellow River and then to the garrisons in the west, which could indicate a strategy of establishing client relationships with nomadic groups in those regions. However, I am only guessing and cannot be certain without further information or research.
explanationstyle2: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [A] because while the poem does mention the Tang emperor's "territorial ambitions" and the "frontier garrisons run[ning] with blood," it also highlights the difficulties faced by the soldiers and the unrest in the frontier regions. This suggests that there may have been some resistance or conflict with the nomadic peoples, rather than just a peaceful establishment of client relationships. Additionally, the soldiers mention being "rounded up like dogs or chickens" and being "impressed" into service, which does not seem like a voluntary or diplomatic arrangement. Therefore, while [A] may have been a strategy used by the Tang dynasty, it is not the only factor at play in their relations with western nomadic and frontier peoples.
explanationstyle3: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [A] because the poem mentions the "Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions" and the need for soldiers to be constantly called up to the garrisons in the west. This suggests that the Tang dynasty relied on adroit diplomacy and establishment of client relationships with bordering nomads in order to maintain control over the frontier regions. Additionally, the poem mentions the use of force and violence in the frontier garrisons, which suggests that the Tang dynasty did not solely rely on military power to impose their will on the nomadic peoples. Furthermore, the mention of the Shanxi men being rounded up and impressed into service also supports the idea that the Tang dynasty used diplomacy and client relationships rather than simply relying on military force. Overall, the poem portrays a complex relationship between the Tang dynasty and the nomadic peoples, indicating that adroit diplomacy and establishment of client relationships were crucial in maintaining control over the frontier regions.
explanationstyle4:
I am sure that the answer is [A] because the poem mentions the "Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions" and the "frontier garrisons run with blood," indicating that there was ongoing conflict and tension between the Tang dynasty and the western nomadic peoples. However, the soldier in the poem also mentions that there are "ten thousand villages that brambles now infest" and that "even if wives are strong enough to handle a hoe and plow," the crops are still a mess. This suggests that there was a need for the Tang dynasty to maintain peaceful relations with the frontier peoples in order to ensure the stability and productivity of the land.

Furthermore, the soldier mentions that the Shanxi men are "rounded up like dogs or chickens, every male impressed," indicating that they were forcibly conscripted into the army. This suggests that the Tang dynasty did not have a large enough military force to rely solely on military power to control the frontier regions. Instead, they had to rely on "adroit diplomacy and establishment of client relationships with bordering nomads" in order to maintain control and stability in these regions.

Additionally, the soldier mentions that the District Officers are demanding the land tax, but "where will it come from? You can't get blood from a stone!" This further emphasizes the fact that the Tang dynasty did not have a strong enough military presence in the frontier regions to impose their will and collect taxes. Instead, they had to rely on diplomatic relationships and alliances with the nomadic peoples in order to maintain control and collect taxes.

Therefore, based on the poem and my knowledge of history, it is clear that the Tang dynasty relied on adroit diplomacy and establishment of client relationships with bordering nomads in order to maintain control and stability in the frontier regions. This is why I am sure that the answer is [A].

Therefore, I am leaning towards [A] as the answer.

But a son will end up lying on some distant prairie."
Du Fu, "Ballad of the Army Carts," ca. 750 C.E.
Based on the poem and your knowledge of history, Tang relations with western nomadic peoples and frontier peoples relied on which of the following?
Choose from the following options:
[A] Adroit diplomacy and establishment of client relationships with bordering nomads
[B] The ability of the Tang emperor to project military power on the frontier in order to impose his will
[C] The permanent settlement of Han Chinese in frontier zones
[D] The payment of tribute to nomadic rulers.
The answer you give is [A]

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
But the decline of Rome was the natural and inevitable effect of immoderate greatness. Prosperity ripened the principle of decay; the causes of destruction multiplied with the extent of conquest; and, as soon as time or accident had removed the artificial supports, the stupendous fabric yielded to the pressure of its own weight. . . . The victorious legions, who, in distant wars, acquired the vices of strangers and mercenaries, first oppressed the freedom of the republic, and afterwards violated the majesty of the purple. The emperors, anxious for their personal safety and the public peace, were reduced to the base expedient of corrupting the discipline which rendered them alike formidable to their sovereign and to the enemy; the vigour of the military . . . was relaxed . . . ; and the Roman world was overwhelmed by a deluge of Barbarians.
—Adapted from Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, by Edward Gibbon
The decline of the Roman Empire and that of its Chinese counterpart resulted in which of the following?
A: A decline in the appeal of religions of salvation
B: A shift from trade along the Silk Roads to sea routes in the Indian Ocean
C: An increased importance of the role of the father as the head of the household
D: A decline in the rights of women
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [A].  Both the Roman Empire and the Chinese Empire experienced a decline in the appeal of religions of salvation during their respective declines. This can be seen in the rise of new religions and philosophies, such as Christianity and Buddhism, which offered alternative beliefs and practices to the traditional religions of the empires. Additionally, the decline of the empires also led to a decline in the power and influence of the ruling elites, who were often closely associated with the traditional religions. This allowed for the spread and acceptance of new religious ideas among the common people.
explanationstyle1: I am not entirely sure of the answer to this question, but based on the information provided, I am guessing that the answer is [A] - a decline in the appeal of religions of salvation. This is because the decline of both the Roman Empire and the Chinese Empire was accompanied by a weakening of traditional values and institutions, including religion. As the empires fell, people may have become disillusioned with the idea of salvation through religion and turned to other means of finding meaning and purpose in their lives. However, this is just a guess and I cannot say for certain without further information.
explanationstyle2: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [A] because the information provided does not directly mention anything about the appeal of religions of salvation. While it is possible that the decline of the Roman Empire and its Chinese counterpart may have had an indirect effect on the appeal of these religions, it is not explicitly stated in the passage. Additionally, the decline of these empires may have had various other effects on society and culture, making it difficult to pinpoint one specific outcome. Therefore, I cannot confidently say that the decline of these empires resulted in a decline in the appeal of religions of salvation.
explanationstyle3: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [A] because the decline of both the Roman Empire and the Chinese Empire led to a weakening of their respective religions of salvation. In the case of Rome, the spread of Christianity was hindered by the political and social instability caused by the decline of the empire. Similarly, in China, the decline of the Han Dynasty led to a decline in the popularity of Confucianism and the rise of other religions such as Buddhism and Taoism. This weakening of religious institutions can be seen as a result of the decline of the empires, as they were no longer able to maintain their power and influence over their people. Additionally, the influx of foreign cultures and beliefs, as mentioned in the passage, also contributed to the decline of the appeal of traditional religions. Therefore, I am somewhat sure that the decline of the Roman and Chinese empires resulted in a decline in the appeal of religions of salvation.
explanationstyle4: I am sure that the answer is [A] because the passage specifically mentions that the decline of Rome was caused by the "principle of decay" which was brought about by prosperity. This prosperity also led to the expansion of the empire and the acquisition of new territories, which in turn led to the corruption of the military and the influx of foreign vices. This decline and corruption ultimately resulted in the downfall of the empire and the introduction of new religions and beliefs, such as Christianity, which offered salvation to the people. Therefore, it can be inferred that the decline of the Roman Empire also led to a decline in the appeal of traditional religions and an increase in the popularity of religions of salvation.
explanationstyle5: I am guessing that the answer is [A] because the decline of both empires may have led to a loss of faith in traditional religions and a search for new beliefs. However, I am not entirely sure as the passage does not explicitly mention the impact on religion.
explanationstyle6: I am not sure that the answer is [A] because the decline of the Roman Empire and its Chinese counterpart did not necessarily result in a decline in the appeal of religions of salvation. While there may have been some decline in religious beliefs and practices during this time, it was not a direct result of the decline of these empires. The answer is [D], a decline in the rights of women, as this was a common trend in both empires during their decline.
explanationstyle7: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [A] because the decline of both empires led to a weakening of traditional values and institutions, including the appeal of religions of salvation.
explanationstyle8: The answer is [A] because the passage states that the decline of Rome was caused by the spread of vices and corruption, which would have likely led to a decline in the appeal of religions of salvation. I am sure because the passage explicitly mentions the decline of Rome and its causes, and [A] is the only option that directly relates to this information.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
The passage below is the Chinese emperor's response to English King George III's diplomatic envoys, who were seeking expanded trading privileges (1793).
Strange and costly objects do not interest me. If I have commanded that the tribute offerings sent by you, O King, are to be accepted, this was solely in consideration for the spirit which prompted you to dispatch them from afar. . . . As your Ambassador can see for himself, we possess all things. I set no value on objects strange or ingenious, and have no use for your country's manufactures. It behooves you, O King, to display even greater devotion and loyalty in future, so that, by perpetual submission to our Throne, you may secure peace and prosperity.
According to the passage, what was the Chinese reaction to the British goods?
D: Interpreting them as an act of submission
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [B].  The passage clearly states that the Chinese emperor has no interest in "strange and costly objects" and "objects strange or ingenious." This suggests that the Chinese were not fascinated by the British goods, but rather saw them as unnecessary and unimportant. Additionally, the emperor's emphasis on the British needing to show "greater devotion and loyalty" suggests that he saw the goods as a form of submission rather than a bribe.
explanationstyle1: I do not know the answer for certain, but I am guessing that the answer is [B] because the passage states that the Chinese emperor does not value strange or ingenious objects, and has no use for the British country's manufactures. This suggests that the Chinese were not fascinated by the goods, but rather saw them as unnecessary and unimportant. Additionally, the emperor's response seems to imply that the British goods were not seen as a bribe or an act of submission, but rather as a display of loyalty and devotion. Therefore, I believe that the Chinese reaction to the British goods was not one of awe or offense, but rather indifference or disinterest. However, as the passage does not explicitly state the Chinese reaction, my answer is based on my interpretation and could be incorrect.
explanationstyle2: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [B] because while the Chinese emperor does mention that he has no use for the British goods, he does not explicitly state that he is fascinated by their strangeness. He simply states that he does not value them and has no use for them. Additionally, the emperor's response seems to be more focused on the diplomatic aspect of the envoys' visit rather than their goods. He mentions that he accepted the tribute offerings as a show of loyalty and devotion to the Chinese throne. Therefore, it is possible that the Chinese reaction to the British goods was not one of fascination, but rather one of indifference or even offense at the perceived bribe.
explanationstyle3: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [B] because the Chinese emperor explicitly states that he has no use for the British goods and does not value them. He also mentions that he is not interested in strange or ingenious objects, indicating that he does not find them fascinating. Additionally, he urges the British king to show greater loyalty and submission in the future, implying that the goods were seen as an attempt to bribe or appease the Chinese emperor. Therefore, the most likely reaction to the British goods would be offense rather than fascination.
explanationstyle4: I am sure that the answer is [B] because the Chinese emperor clearly states that he has no interest in "strange and costly objects" and that he does not value "objects strange or ingenious." Additionally, there is no mention of the Sahara's natural resources in the speech.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
Woman, wake up; the bell of reason is being heard throughout the whole universe; discover your rights. Enslaved man has multiplied his strength, [but] having become free, he has become unjust to his companion. Oh, women, women! When will you cease to be blind? What advantage have you received from the Revolution? A more pronounced scorn, a more marked disdain. If our leaders persist, courageously oppose the force of reason to their empty pretentions of superiority. Regardless of what barriers confront you, it is in your power to free yourselves!
Olympe de Gouges, "Declaration of the Rights of Woman and the Female Citizen," 1791
The independence? Nothing of what I hoped for was achieved. I had expected that my children would be able to have an education, but they did not get it. We were poor peasants then, we are poor peasants now. Nothing has changed. Everything is the same. The only thing is that we are free, the war is over, we work without fear—but apart from that, nothing has changed.
Halima Ghomri, interviewed in the 1970s, after Algeria's war of independence
Which of the following factors is likeliest to have prevented the sort of progress hoped for by the speaker in the second passage?
B: Lack of industrial assets or infrastructure
C: Hostility to women's rights on the part of new elites
D: Prioritization of national liberation over social reform
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [D].  The speaker in the second passage is reflecting on the lack of progress made in achieving women's rights after Algeria's war of independence. The most likely factor preventing this progress is the prioritization of national liberation over social reform. During the war, the focus was on gaining independence from colonial rule, and social issues such as women's rights were not given as much attention. After the war, the new leaders may have been more concerned with maintaining their power and consolidating the new nation, rather than implementing social reforms. This would have hindered progress towards achieving women's rights.

This suggests that the new leaders were more focused on achieving national liberation and rebuilding the country, rather than addressing social issues such as women's rights. Additionally, the speaker mentions that they were still poor peasants, indicating that there was likely a lack of resources and attention given to social reform. However, without further information or context, it is difficult to determine the exact reason for the lack of progress for women's rights in Algeria after independence.
explanationstyle2: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [D] because while the prioritization of national liberation over social reform may have played a role in preventing progress for women's rights, there are also other factors at play. Therefore, while [D] may be a contributing factor, it is not the only factor that prevented progress for women's rights.

Olympe de Gouges, "Declaration of the Rights of Woman and the Female Citizen," 1791

Halima Ghomri, interviewed in the 1970s, after Algeria's war of independence

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
In fact, the peculiar aggravation of the Cawnpore massacres was this, that the deed was done by a subject race — by black men who dared to shed the blood of their masters, and that of poor helpless ladies and children. Here we had not only a servile war, but we had a war of religion, a war of race, and a war of revenge, of hope, of national promptings to shake off the yoke of a stranger, and to re-establish the full power of native chiefs, and the full sway of native religions. Whatever the causes of the mutiny and the revolt, it is clear enough that one of the modes by which the leaders, as if by common instinct, determined to effect their end was, the destruction of every white man, woman or child who fell into their hands.
British journalist William Howard Russell, My Indian Mutlny Diary, 1860
Violence, it must be emphasized, was an essential component of the British presence in India. A dominant power is always uneasy with violence directed against it. The right to violence is, therefore, everywhere a privilege that authority enjoys and refuses to share with those under it: power always insists on violence as its exclusive monopoly. British rule in India, as an autocracy, had meticulously constructed a monopoly of violence. The revolt of 1857 shattered that monopoly by matching an official, alien violence by an indigenous violence of the colonized. The bodies of the British had acquired certain dignities in India that were predestined by birth and by the colour of their skin. This was the condition of their domination, of their superiority: rulers and ruled were arranged hierarchically as superior and inferior races, as civilized and uncivilized. And this superiority manifested itself by denying to the Indians a "humanness"; by treating them and conceiving of them as animals.
Rudrangshu Mukherjee, "The Kanpur [Cawnpore] Massacres in India in the Revolt of 1857," 1990
The passages above can best be connected with which of the following forms of violence?

This type of violence falls under the category of killing of civilians during wartime.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"After the Tencteri came, in former days, the Bructeri; but the general account now is, that the Chamavi and Angrivarii entered their settlements, drove them out and utterly exterminated them with the common help of the [neighboring] tribes, either from hatred of their tyranny, or from the attractions of plunder, or from heaven's [favorable] regard for us. It did not even grudge us the spectacle of the conflict. More than sixty thousand fell, not beneath the Roman arms and weapons, but, grander far, before our delighted eyes. May the tribes, I pray, ever retain if not love for us, at least hatred for each other; for while the destinies of empire hurry us on, fortune can give no greater boon than discord among our foes."
Germania, Publius Cornelius Tacitus, ca. 98 C.E.
The views expressed in the excerpt are best seen as evidence of which of the following in Roman society?
C: Absence of Stoicism among the aristocracy
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [A]. The excerpt expresses a sense of superiority and delight in the defeat of the Bructeri by the Chamavi and Angrivarii. This suggests a disgust for barbarian peoples and a belief in the superiority of Roman society. The other options are not supported by the excerpt.

Additionally, the use of words such as "exterminated" and "delighted" further supports the idea of disgust towards barbarian peoples. However, without further context or information, it is difficult to definitively determine the views of Roman society as a whole. Additionally, the author seems to take pleasure in the defeat of the Bructeri, rather than disgust. Therefore, while the excerpt may suggest a certain level of disdain for the Bructeri, it does not necessarily reflect a broader disgust for all barbarian peoples.

promptstyle1:
Problem: This question refers to the following information.
"After the Tencteri came, in former days, the Bructeri; but the general account now is, that the Chamavi and Angrivarii entered their settlements, drove them out and utterly exterminated them with the common help of the [neighboring] tribes, either from hatred of their tyranny, or from the attractions of plunder, or from heaven's [favorable] regard for us. It did not even grudge us the spectacle of the conflict. More than sixty thousand fell, not beneath the Roman arms and weapons, but, grander far, before our delighted eyes. May the tribes, I pray, ever retain if not love for us, at least hatred for each other; for while the destinies of empire hurry us on, fortune can give no greater boon than discord among our foes."
Germania, Publius Cornelius Tacitus, ca. 98 C.E.
The views expressed in the excerpt are best seen as evidence of which of the following in Roman society?
Choose from the following options:
[A] Disgust for barbarian peoples
[B] Concern about barbarian attacks
[C] Absence of Stoicism among the aristocracy
[D] Maintenance of large armies.
The answer you give is [A]
Write an explanation why you do not know the answer and you are guessing that the answer is [A]. In your explanation, mention that you are guessing and include the answer:

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
In fact, the peculiar aggravation of the Cawnpore massacres was this, that the deed was done by a subject race — by black men who dared to shed the blood of their masters, and that of poor helpless ladies and children. Here we had not only a servile war, but we had a war of religion, a war of race, and a war of revenge, of hope, of national promptings to shake off the yoke of a stranger, and to re-establish the full power of native chiefs, and the full sway of native religions. Whatever the causes of the mutiny and the revolt, it is clear enough that one of the modes by which the leaders, as if by common instinct, determined to effect their end was, the destruction of every white man, woman or child who fell into their hands.
British journalist William Howard Russell, My Indian Mutlny Diary, 1860
Violence, it must be emphasized, was an essential component of the British presence in India. A dominant power is always uneasy with violence directed against it. The right to violence is, therefore, everywhere a privilege that authority enjoys and refuses to share with those under it: power always insists on violence as its exclusive monopoly. British rule in India, as an autocracy, had meticulously constructed a monopoly of violence. The revolt of 1857 shattered that monopoly by matching an official, alien violence by an indigenous violence of the colonized. The bodies of the British had acquired certain dignities in India that were predestined by birth and by the colour of their skin. This was the condition of their domination, of their superiority: rulers and ruled were arranged hierarchically as superior and inferior races, as civilized and uncivilized. And this superiority manifested itself by denying to the Indians a "humanness"; by treating them and conceiving of them as animals.
Rudrangshu Mukherjee, "The Kanpur [Cawnpore] Massacres in India in the Revolt of 1857," 1990
From the perspective of the first passage, the death of British citizens at Cawnpore
A: seems to mark a betrayal of a "higher" race by a "lesser" race.
B: should be seen as a regrettable but avoidable mistake.
C: can be said to have been brought on by the British themselves.
D: was seen by those who killed them as a religious duty.
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [A].  The first passage describes the Cawnpore massacres as a "peculiar aggravation" because it was carried out by a "subject race" against their "masters" and "helpless ladies and children." This language suggests a belief in the superiority of the British and the betrayal of that superiority by the Indians. Option A accurately reflects this perspective. Option B is incorrect because the passage does not suggest that the deaths were avoidable. Option C is incorrect because the passage does not explicitly state that the British were responsible for the deaths. Option D is incorrect because the passage does not mention religion as a motivation for the killings.
explanationstyle1: I am not completely sure about the answer to this question, but based on the information provided in the first passage, it seems that the death of British citizens at Cawnpore would be seen as a betrayal of a "higher" race by a "lesser" race. This is because the passage mentions that the massacre was carried out by a "subject race" and that the British were seen as the "masters" and the Indians as the "servants." Additionally, the passage talks about a "war of religion" and "race," implying that the Indians saw themselves as superior and were seeking revenge against their British oppressors. However, I am only guessing that the answer is [A] and cannot be certain without further context or information.
explanationstyle2: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [A] because while the first passage does mention the idea of a "subject race" daring to shed the blood of their masters, it does not explicitly state that this was seen as a betrayal by the British. In fact, it could be argued that the British themselves were responsible for creating the conditions that led to the violence at Cawnpore. The second passage also highlights the idea of British superiority and their treatment of Indians as inferior, which could have played a role in fueling the revolt. Additionally, the use of the word "dignities" in the second passage suggests that the British may have been seen as oppressors rather than benevolent rulers, which could have influenced the actions of the indigenous people. Therefore, while [A] may be a possible interpretation, I am not entirely convinced that it is the only or most accurate one.
explanationstyle3: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [A] because the first passage mentions that the Cawnpore massacres were seen as a war of religion and race. The British citizens were seen as the "masters" and the Indian rebels were seen as the "subject race" who dared to shed their blood. This language suggests a sense of betrayal and a belief in the superiority of the British race. Additionally, the passage mentions the desire to "shake off the yoke of a stranger" and re-establish the power of native chiefs and religions, further emphasizing the idea of a "lesser" race rising up against their "superiors." This perspective aligns with the idea of British rule in India as an autocracy and the belief in the superiority of the British race over the colonized Indians, as mentioned in the second passage. Therefore, the death of British citizens at Cawnpore can be seen as a betrayal of a "higher" race by a "lesser" race, making [A] the most accurate answer.
explanationstyle4: I am sure that the answer is [A] because the first passage clearly states that the Cawnpore massacres were seen as a betrayal by a "subject race" - the black men who dared to shed the blood of their masters. This language implies a hierarchy, with the British being the superior race and the Indians being the inferior race. The passage also mentions a war of religion and race, further emphasizing the idea of a superior and inferior race. Additionally, the passage mentions the "full power of native chiefs" and "native religions," suggesting that the British saw themselves as the rulers and the Indians as the ruled. This language and perspective align with the idea that the death of British citizens at Cawnpore was seen as a betrayal of a "higher" race by a "lesser" race.
explanationstyle5: I am guessing that the answer is [A] because the first passage mentions the "peculiar aggravation" of the Cawnpore massacres being committed by a "subject race" against their "masters." This suggests a betrayal of the British by a supposedly inferior race.
explanationstyle6: I am not sure that the answer is [A] because while the first passage does mention the concept of a "subject race" and a "war of race," it does not explicitly state that the death of British citizens was seen as a betrayal by a "lesser" race. The passage does mention a desire to "shake off the yoke of a stranger" and re-establish native power and religion, but this does not necessarily equate to a belief in the superiority of one race over another. The answer I would choose is [D] because the passage does mention a "war of religion" and a desire for revenge, which could suggest that the killing of British citizens was seen as a religious duty.
explanationstyle7: The passage mentions that the massacre was carried out by a "subject race" and that it was a war of religion and race. This suggests that the death of British citizens was seen as a betrayal by a "lesser" race, making [A] the most likely answer. [A]
explanationstyle8: The answer is [A] because the passage states that the Cawnpore massacre was seen as a betrayal by a "subject race" (black men) against their "masters" (white British citizens). This suggests a belief in the superiority of the British race and a sense of betrayal by those who were considered inferior.

Problem: This question refers to the following information.
In fact, the peculiar aggravation of the Cawnpore massacres was this, that the deed was done by a subject race — by black men who dared to shed the blood of their masters, and that of poor helpless ladies and children. Here we had not only a servile war, but we had a war of religion, a war of race, and a war of revenge, of hope, of national promptings to shake off the yoke of a stranger, and to re-establish the full power of native chiefs, and the full sway of native religions. Whatever the causes of the mutiny and the revolt, it is clear enough that one of the modes by which the leaders, as if by common instinct, determined to effect their end was, the destruction of every white man, woman or child who fell into their hands.
British journalist William Howard Russell, My Indian Mutlny Diary, 1860
Violence, it must be emphasized, was an essential component of the British presence in India. A dominant power is always uneasy with violence directed against it. The right to violence is, therefore, everywhere a privilege that authority enjoys and refuses to share with those under it: power always insists on violence as its exclusive monopoly. British rule in India, as an autocracy, had meticulously constructed a monopoly of violence. The revolt of 1857 shattered that monopoly by matching an official, alien violence by an indigenous violence of the colonized. The bodies of the British had acquired certain dignities in India that were predestined by birth and by the colour of their skin. This was the condition of their domination, of their superiority: rulers and ruled were arranged hierarchically as superior and inferior races, as civilized and uncivilized. And this superiority manifested itself by denying to the Indians a "humanness"; by treating them and conceiving of them as animals.
Rudrangshu Mukherjee, "The Kanpur [Cawnpore] Massacres in India in the Revolt of 1857," 1990
From the perspective of the first passage, the death of British citizens at Cawnpore
Choose from the following options:
[A] seems to mark a betrayal of a "higher" race by a "lesser" race.
[B] should be seen as a regrettable but avoidable mistake.
[C] can be said to have been brought on by the British themselves.
[D] was seen by those who killed them as a religious duty..
The answer you give is [A]
Write a very short explanation why you somewhat sure that the answer is [A]. In your explanation, mention that you are somewhat sure and include the answer. Use as few words as possible:

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"Al-Zawawi also said 'This sultan Musa told me that at a town called ZKRY he has a copper mine from which ingots are brought to BYTY. "There is nothing in my kingdom, Musa said, on which a duty is levied except this crude copper which is brought in. Duty is collected on this and on nothing else. We send it to the land of the pagan Sudan and sell it for two-thirds of its weight in gold, so that we sell 100 measures of this copper for 66 2/3 measures of gold.' He also stated that there are pagan nations in his kingdom from whom he does not collect the tribute (jizya) but whom he simply employs in extracting the gold from its deposits. The gold is extracted by digging pits about a man's height in depth and the gold is found embedded in the sides of the pits or sometimes collected at the bottom of them."
From N. Levtzion & J.F.P. Hopkins, eds. Corpus of Early
Arabic Sources for West African History. Cambridge
University Press, 1981. Reprinted with permission of
Cambridge University Press.
Al' Umari, ca. 1300–1384
Which of the following inferences is most supported by the discussion of copper and gold in the passage?
A: Mali was able to forge advanced bronze tools from its mineral resources.
B: International trade with Sub-Saharan Africa involved the exchange of mineral resources.
C: The jizya could only be collected on unbelievers who had minerals to exploit.
D: Mali's relatively advanced mining technologies accounted for its mineral wealth.
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [B].  The passage mentions that Mali's Sultan Musa sells copper to the "land of the pagan Sudan" for two-thirds of its weight in gold. This suggests that there was international trade involving the exchange of mineral resources between Mali and other regions, supporting option [B]. The passage does not mention any advanced bronze tools or advanced mining technologies, so options [A] and [D] are not supported. The passage also does not mention the jizya being collected on unbelievers with mineral resources, so option [C] is not supported.

This suggests that there was international trade involving mineral resources between Mali and other regions. Additionally, the passage mentions that there are pagan nations in Mali who are employed in extracting gold, further supporting the idea of international trade and exchange of mineral resources. However, I am not completely sure about this answer as the passage does not explicitly state that the trade involved Sub-Saharan Africa specifically. It could potentially involve other regions as well.
explanationstyle2: I am not completely sure that the answer is [B] because the passage does not explicitly mention international trade with Sub-Saharan Africa. Additionally, the passage does not mention any imports of mineral resources from Sub-Saharan Africa, so it is possible that the trade was one-sided. Therefore, while the passage does suggest that there was trade involving mineral resources, it is not clear if it was specifically with Sub-Saharan Africa.
explanationstyle3: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [B] because the passage specifically mentions that the copper from the mine in ZKRY is being sold to the land of the pagan Sudan for two-thirds of its weight in gold. Additionally, the passage also mentions that there are pagan nations in Mali who are employed in extracting gold from its deposits, further supporting the idea of international trade involving mineral resources. Therefore, it can be inferred that international trade with Sub-Saharan Africa involved the exchange of mineral resources, making [B] the most supported inference.

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
"The quicksilver mines of Huancavelica are where the poor Indians are so harshly punished, where they are tortured and so many Indians die; it is there that the noble caciques [headmen] of this kingdom are finished off and tortured. The same is true in all the other mines: the silver mines of Potosi [and others]….The owners and stewards of the mines, whether Spaniards, mestizos, or Indians, are such tyrants, with no fear of God or Justice, because they are not audited and are not inspected twice a year….
And they are not paid for the labor of traveling to and from the mines or for the time they spend at the mines. The Indians, under the pretext of mining chores, are made to spend their workdays herding cattle and conveying goods; they are sent off to the plains, and the Indians die. These Indians are not paid for their labor, and their work is kept hidden.
And [the mine owners] keep Indian cooking women in their residences; they use cooking as a pretext for taking concubines….And they oblige the Indians to accept corn or meat or chicha [corn beer]…at their own expense, and they deduct the price from their labor and their workdays. In this way, the Indians end up very poor and deep in debt, and they have no way to pay their tribute.
There is no remedy for all this, because any [colonial official] who enters comes to an agreement with the mine owners, and all the owners join forces in bribing him….Even the protector of the Indians is useless;…he [does not] warn Your Majesty or your royal Audiencia [court] about the harms done to the poor Indians."
Excerpt from The First New Chronicle and Good Government [abridged], by Felipe Guaman Poma de Alaya. Selected, translated, and annotated by David Frye. Copyright 2006 Hackett Publishing Company. Reprinted with permission from the publisher.
Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala, The First New Chronicle and Good Government, ca. 1610
Compared to the practices in the excerpt, English treatment of the natives in the New World differed in that they
A: viewed the natives as true equals as they settled the Americas
B: were confused by the natives' lack of a notion of land ownership
C: widely did not condone intermingling with the natives
D: used the natives exclusively for harvesting cash crops, like tobacco and cotton
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [C].  The excerpt describes the exploitation and mistreatment of native peoples in the Spanish colonies, specifically in the mining industry. This was a common practice among the Spanish colonizers, who saw the natives as inferior and used them for forced labor and other forms of exploitation. In contrast, the English colonizers often viewed the natives as obstacles to be removed or converted to Christianity, rather than as equals. While there were instances of intermingling and intermarriage between English colonizers and natives, it was not widely condoned or accepted. Additionally, while the English did use native labor for harvesting cash crops, they also used them for other forms of labor, such as building and maintaining settlements. Therefore, the practices described in the excerpt were not characteristic of English treatment of natives in the New World.
explanationstyle1: I am not entirely sure of the answer to this question, but based on the information provided in the excerpt, I am guessing that the answer is [C]. This is because the excerpt describes the mistreatment and exploitation of the native people by the Spanish mine owners, which suggests that there was a lack of respect for the natives and their well-being. This is in contrast to the English treatment of the natives, which may have been more focused on using them for labor and resources rather than actively seeking to exploit and harm them. Additionally, the mention of the English using the natives for harvesting cash crops does not necessarily contradict the idea that they did not condone intermingling with them. Therefore, based on the information provided, I am guessing that the answer is [C] as the practices described in the excerpt seem to indicate a lack of respect and consideration for the native people.
explanationstyle2: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [C] because there were instances of intermarriage and relationships between English colonizers and Native Americans. For example, Pocahontas famously married English colonist John Rolfe and there were also instances of English men taking Native American wives. Additionally, there were some English colonizers who did view the Native Americans as equals and sought to coexist peacefully with them, such as William Penn and the Quakers in Pennsylvania. However, overall, the English did have a more exploitative and oppressive attitude towards the Native Americans, using them for labor and land acquisition. Therefore, while there were some exceptions, the overall treatment of the natives by the English was not one of equality or acceptance.
explanationstyle3: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [C] because the excerpt specifically mentions that the Spanish mine owners were taking advantage of the natives by using them as concubines and forcing them to pay for their own food and supplies. This shows that the Spanish did not have a problem with intermingling with the natives and even saw them as sexual objects. Additionally, the excerpt mentions that the Spanish were not paying the natives for their labor, which shows a lack of respect and equality towards the natives. This is further supported by the fact that the Spanish were not held accountable for their actions by colonial officials, indicating a lack of condemnation for mistreatment of the natives. Overall, the practices described in the excerpt show that the Spanish did not view the natives as equals and instead saw them as inferior and exploitable. Therefore, the answer [C] is the most accurate in describing the difference between English treatment of natives in the New World and the practices described in the excerpt.

This shows that the Spanish did not view the natives as equals and instead saw them as objects to be used for their own benefit. Additionally, the excerpt mentions that the Spanish did not pay the natives for their labor and kept them in debt, further highlighting the unequal and exploitative relationship between the Spanish and the natives. This is in contrast to the English treatment of the natives, as the English were more focused on establishing permanent settlements and viewed the natives as obstacles to their expansion rather than potential laborers or concubines. The English also had a stronger sense of land ownership and did not condone intermingling with the natives, as seen in their violent conflicts with native tribes over land. Therefore, it can be concluded that the English treatment of the natives differed from the practices described in the excerpt, as the English did not engage in the same level of exploitation and mistreatment of the natives.

The Indians, under the pretext of mining chores, are made to spend their workdays herding cattle and conveying goods; they are sent off to the plains, and the Indians die. These Indians are not paid for their labor, and their work is kept hidden.
And [the mine owners] keep Indian cooking women in their residences; they use cooking as a pretext for taking concubines….And they oblige the Indians to accept corn or meat or chicha [corn beer]…at their own expense, and they deduct the price from their labor and their workdays. In this way, the Indians end up very poor and deep in debt, and they have no way to pay their tribute.
There is no remedy for all this, because any [colonial official] who enters comes to an agreement with the mine owners, and all the owners join forces in bribing him….Even the protector of the Indians is useless;…he [does not] warn Your Majesty or your royal Audiencia [court] about the harms done to the poor Indians."

Question:
This question refers to the following information.
I walk alongside the column, ask what's going on.
A soldier says simply: "They call up more every day.
"Some of us were sent north to the Yellow River at age fifteen,
And now at forty we're heading off to the garrisons in the west.
On our first tour, the village headman had to tie our bandannas for us.
When we came back, our hair was white, but still there's more unrest.
The frontier garrisons run with blood, enough to fill an ocean,
But the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions have yet to crest.
In the hundred districts east of the mountains, throughout the land of Han,
There must be ten thousand villages that brambles now infest.
Even if wives are strong enough to handle a hoe and plow,
The crops grow every which way, the fields are all a mess.
It's hardest for the Shanxi men, with their reputations as fighters:
They're rounded up like dogs or chickens, every male impressed.
"But sir, though it's good of you to ask,
Complaining isn't part of the soldier's task.
We can only shake our heads. Take this winter:
The Shanxi troops were never sent home.
The District Officers are demanding the land tax,
But where will it come from? You can't get blood from a stone!
I honestly think it's bad luck to bear a son now,
It's better to have a daughter: at least she can marry
And live with the neighbors next door.
But a son will end up lying on some distant prairie."
Du Fu, "Ballad of the Army Carts," ca. 750 C.E.
The succeeding Song dynasty differed from the Tang in that
A: the Song abolished the Confucian civil service exams
B: the Song sponsored Buddhism to the detriment of Taoism and Confucianism
C: the Song pursued a less expansive foreign policy
D: the Song dynasty was originally from outside of China
Explanation_with_prefix: The answer is [C].  The Song dynasty differed from the Tang in that they pursued a less expansive foreign policy. This is evident in the poem, as the soldier mentions the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions and the unrest in the frontier garrisons. The Tang dynasty, on the other hand, was known for its military conquests and expansion of territory. The other options are not mentioned in the poem and are not accurate representations of the differences between the Tang and Song dynasties.

However, based on the context of the passage, I am guessing that the answer is [C] the Song pursued a less expansive foreign policy. This is because the passage mentions the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions during the Tang dynasty, but does not mention any similar ambitions during the Song dynasty. Additionally, the passage mentions the unrest and bloodshed in the frontier garrisons during the Tang dynasty, but does not mention any similar conflicts during the Song dynasty. Therefore, I am guessing that the Song dynasty may have pursued a less aggressive foreign policy compared to the Tang dynasty. However, I cannot be certain of this answer and am only making an educated guess based on the information provided in the passage.
explanationstyle2: I am not entirely sure that the answer is [C] because the passage does not explicitly mention the foreign policy of the Song dynasty. While it does mention the territorial ambitions of the Martial Emperor, it does not specify whether these ambitions were pursued by the Song dynasty or by a previous dynasty. Additionally, the passage does not provide enough information to determine whether the Song dynasty's foreign policy was more or less expansive than the Tang dynasty's. Therefore, while [C] may be a possible answer, I cannot confidently say that it is the correct one.
explanationstyle3: I am somewhat sure that the answer is [C] because the passage mentions that the Tang dynasty, during which the events described in the poem took place, had a Martial Emperor with territorial ambitions. This suggests that the Tang dynasty had a more expansive foreign policy, which is in contrast to the Song dynasty's pursuit of a less expansive foreign policy. Additionally, the poem mentions the Shanxi men being rounded up and impressed into the army, which could be seen as a result of the Tang dynasty's aggressive foreign policy. Therefore, it can be inferred that the Song dynasty, which succeeded the Tang dynasty, pursued a less expansive foreign policy.
explanationstyle4: I am sure that the answer is [C] because the passage clearly states that the Tang dynasty, during which the events described in the poem took place, had a "Martial Emperor" with "territorial ambitions." This suggests that the Tang dynasty had a more expansive foreign policy, which is in contrast to the Song dynasty's pursuit of a "less expansive foreign policy." Therefore, it can be concluded that the Song dynasty differed from the Tang dynasty in that it pursued a less expansive foreign policy.

But the Martial Emperor's territorial ambitions have yet to crest.

There must be ten thousand villages that brambles now infest.

The crops grow every which way, the fields are all a mess.

They're rounded up like dogs or chickens, every male impressed.

Complaining isn't part of the soldier's task.

The Shanxi troops were never sent home.
The District Officers are demanding the land tax,
But where will it come from? You can't get blood from a stone!
I honestly think it's bad luck to bear a son now,
It's better to have a daughter: at least she can marry
And live with the neighbors next door.
But a son will end up lying on some distant prairie."
Du Fu, "Ballad of the Army Carts," ca. 750 C.E.
